fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By definition, the pullback of the least subterminal object along the unique morphism \mathsf {!}_{A}\colon A\to 1 is the initial object q in \mathsf {Sub}(A). Suppose that there is a morphism f\colon A\to 0. Form the following diagram:
Since q is initial, sq = \mathsf {id}_{0_{A}} by uniqueness. Thus, the initial object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) is isomorphic to its terminal object, i.e., A does not have proper subobjects.

Similarly, the pullback of q along \pi _{1} is the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A). Then s\pi _{1} corresponds to a morphism from the terminal object to the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A).

Thus, A \times A does not have proper subobjects, so in particular, the diagonal map \Delta \colon A\rightarrowtail A \times A is an isomorphism. Since \Delta is the equalizer of \pi _{1} and \pi _{2}, this implies that \pi _{1} = \pi _{2}. Thus, for any parallel pair of morphisms a,b\colon B\rightrightarrows A with codomain A, we have

Thus, \mathsf {!}_{A} is monic. Then the morphism p means that the subterminal object \mathsf {!}_{A}q is contained in the least subterminal object of 1, so p is an isomorphism. Then, f, as the composite of two isomorphisms, is also an isomorphism.

fr:title.text: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strictness of the least subterminal object in a coherent category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a coherent category and 0 \rightarrowtail 1 be the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(1). Then any morphism f\colon A\to 0 in \mathcal {C} is an isomorphism.

By definition, the pullback of the least subterminal object along the unique morphism \mathsf {!}_{A}\colon A\to 1 is the initial object q in \mathsf {Sub}(A). Suppose that there is a morphism f\colon A\to 0. Form the following diagram:
Since q is initial, sq = \mathsf {id}_{0_{A}} by uniqueness. Thus, the initial object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) is isomorphic to its terminal object, i.e., A does not have proper subobjects.

Similarly, the pullback of q along \pi _{1} is the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A). Then s\pi _{1} corresponds to a morphism from the terminal object to the initial object in \mathsf {Sub}(A \times A).

Thus, A \times A does not have proper subobjects, so in particular, the diagonal map \Delta \colon A\rightarrowtail A \times A is an isomorphism. Since \Delta is the equalizer of \pi _{1} and \pi _{2}, this implies that \pi _{1} = \pi _{2}. Thus, for any parallel pair of morphisms a,b\colon B\rightrightarrows A with codomain A, we have

Thus, \mathsf {!}_{A} is monic. Then the morphism p means that the subterminal object \mathsf {!}_{A}q is contained in the least subterminal object of 1, so p is an isomorphism. Then, f, as the composite of two isomorphisms, is also an isomorphism.
